title: Roosters ready for Cronk bin says JWH
text:
While Jared Waerea-Hargreaves may have been the hot favourite to get sin-binned during the NRL grand final, the Sydney Roosters enforcer said his team had also prepared for the loss of Cooper Cronk.

With six offences this season including four trips to the judiciary and missing the preliminary final through suspension, it was easy to assume the Kiwi could step out of line in the grand final cauldron.

But instead cleanskin halfback Cronk was banished to the bin for a professional foul when judged to have tackled Raiders prop Josh Papalii without the ball.

Waerea-Hargreaves said the Roosters training included taking each player, including Cronk, out of their defensive line to prepare for such a scenario.

"Every individual gets taken out; the coach takes an individual out of the team so when Coops left, obviously it wasn't ideal but we knew what we had to do and we dug deep," Waerea-Hargreaves told AAP.

"We train for those moments and when you train for those sort of things you grow under pressure.

"It's uncomfortable but you grow - it was awesome - we showed true character and I'm really proud."

Waerea-Hargreaves was embroiled in a post-match controversy surrounding the Clive Churchill Medal.

The 30-year-old was reportedly told prematurely by an unknown official he had won the award as the grand final man of the match.

He had had a massive first half, running double as many metres as any other forward.

However the message came before Darren Lockyer's votes had been added to those of Laurie Daley and Mal Meninga, with the judging panel actually selecting Canberra's Jack Wighton.

Waerea-Hargreaves didn't seem fazed amidst the celebrations.

"This will go on until we go back to pre-season," he laughed when asked how long the party would go for.

"We are going to ride this out until we start pre-season."
